Finally, he was master of a clear, incisive, picturesque style, peculiarly adapted to the interesting presentation of historica] facts.

With such qualifications, it is no wonder that he at once established a high reputation as a historian, and succeeded to some degree in rivalling his Greek model.

It would be idle to claim that Sallust as a historian had no faults. But in considering these, it is only fair to re- member that our conception of history differs widely from that of the ancientS.
